{{Infobox software | name = XSplash | title = | logo = <!-- [[File: ]] --> | screenshot = <!-- [[File: ]] --> | caption = | collapsible = | author = | developer = Cody Russell, Ken VanDine | released = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | discontinued = | latest release version = 0.8.5 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2009|10|22}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | frequently updated = | programming language = C | operating system = [[Linux]] | platform = | size = | language = | status = | genre = [[Bootsplash]] | license = GNU GPL v3 | website = https://launchpad.net/xsplash }} '''XSplash''' is a [[software]] project in the [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] community that uses the [[X Window System]] to replace the scrolling-text screens that appear while booting a Linux-based computer with a graphical [[splash screen]].
XSplash replaced [[usplash]] (which uses the [[Linux framebuffer]]) in Ubuntu 9.10 ([[List of Ubuntu releases#Ubuntu 9.10 (Karmic Koala)|Karmic Koala]]), bringing Ubuntu closer to its goal of a 10-second boot time by version 10.04 ([[List of Ubuntu releases#Ubuntu 10.04 LTS (Lucid Lynx)|Lucid Lynx]]). The improved boot performance over usplash and other boot systems is achieved by prioritizing startup processes related to the X server, and by using a single X server throughout the boot process<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.netsplit.com/2009/09/02/making-a-splash/ |title=Making a Splash |publisher=Netsplit.com |accessdate=2009-10-31}}</ref>.
